metadata.title: Lockups | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing Lockups, which are UI components that combine multiple separate views into a single, interactive unit. The document covers best practices and four types of lockups: cards, caption buttons, monograms, and posters, primarily for tvOS development.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: Lockups combine multiple separate views into a single, interactive unit.

content.description: A stylized illustration showing a lockup component with a circular avatar placeholder (gray with red accent ring) at the top, and below it two lines of text labeled 'Line 1 (Headline)' and 'Line 2 (Footnote)'. The entire composition demonstrates the structure of a lockup with header content (avatar), main content area, and footer text.
content.composition: Vertically stacked elements - circular avatar at top, text labels below. Clean minimal design with light gray background.
content.technicalDetails: UI component diagram showing lockup anatomy
content.contextualRelevance: Primary illustration demonstrating what a lockup component looks like and its structural elements including header (avatar), content area, and footer (text labels).

content.text: Each lockup consists of a content view, a header, and a footer. Headers appear above the main content for a lockup, and footers appear below the main content. All three views expand and contract together as the lockup gets focus.
According to the needs of your app, you can combine four types of lockup: cards, caption buttons, monograms, and posters.
Allow adequate space between lockups. A focused lockup expands in size, so leave enough room between lockups to avoid overlapping or displacing other lockups. For guidance, see Layout.

content.description: A diagram showing three rectangular lockup placeholders arranged horizontally in a row, with adequate spacing between them. The lockups are shown as light gray rounded rectangles with slightly darker borders, demonstrating the recommended spacing pattern.
content.composition: Three identical rounded rectangles arranged horizontally with equal spacing between them.
content.technicalDetails: Layout diagram showing proper spacing between lockup components
content.contextualRelevance: Illustrates the best practice of allowing adequate space between lockups to prevent overlap when focused.

content.text: Use consistent lockup sizes within a row or group. A group of buttons or a row of content images is more visually appealing when the widths and heights of all elements match.

boldPhrases: Use consistent lockup sizes within a row or group.

content.text: For developer guidance, see TVLockupView and TVLockupHeaderFooterView.
A card combines a header, footer, and content view to present ratings and reviews for media items.

content.description: A card lockup component showing a media rating card. The card has a header section with 'Title' text, below which is a rating display showing '4/5' with star icons. The main content area shows a large rectangular placeholder (light gray), and at the bottom are 5 circular user avatars (gray placeholders) representing reviewers. The card has a subtle shadow effect.
content.composition: Vertical stack: title at top, rating below, large content rectangle in middle, row of 5 circular avatars at bottom.
content.technicalDetails: TVCardView example showing ratings and reviews layout
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the card lockup type used for presenting ratings and reviews for media items.

content.text: A caption button can include a title and a subtitle beneath the button. A caption button can contain either an image or text.

Make sure that when people focus on them, caption buttons tilt with the motion that they swipe. When aligned vertically, caption buttons tilt up and down. When aligned horizontally, caption buttons tilt left and right. When displayed in a grid, caption buttons tilt both vertically and horizontally.

boldPhrases: Make sure that when people focus on them, caption buttons tilt with the motion that they swipe.

content.description: A set of caption buttons arranged in two rows. The top row shows 4 rounded rectangular buttons with placeholder content. The bottom row shows 4 caption buttons with icons and labels beneath them: 'Audio' (speaker icon), 'CC' (closed captions icon), 'Subs' (subtitles icon), and 'Info' (information icon). Each button is a rounded rectangle with the icon centered inside, and the text label appears below the button.
content.composition: Two rows of buttons. Top row: 4 content placeholders. Bottom row: 4 labeled icon buttons arranged horizontally.
content.technicalDetails: TVCaptionButtonView examples showing icon buttons with captions
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates caption button lockups with icons and text labels, commonly used for media playback controls.

content.text: Monograms identify people, usually the cast and crew for a media item. Each monogram consists of a circular picture of the person and their name. If an image isn't available, the person's initials appear in place of an image.
Prefer images over initials. An image of a person creates a more intimate connection than text.

content.description: A monogram lockup component showing a large circular avatar placeholder in the center with a gray background and a person silhouette icon. Below the circle is the text 'Title.' representing where the person's name would appear. Above the monogram are some placeholder rectangular shapes representing a media context. The monogram also shows 'Title.' label.
content.composition: Large circular avatar centered with title text below. Additional content placeholders above.
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates monogram lockups used to identify people such as cast and crew members.

content.text: Posters consist of an image and an optional title and subtitle, which are hidden until the poster comes into focus. Posters can be any size, but the size needs to be appropriate for their content. For related guidance, see Image views.
Not supported in iOS, iPadOS, macOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

legalSection.feedbackText: To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.
legalSection.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Developer Documentation page for Lockups - tvOS UI components that combine header, content, and footer views into interactive units. Covers four lockup types (cards, caption buttons, monograms, posters) with best practices and developer API references.

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduces lockups as UI components that combine content view, header, and footer into a single interactive unit that expands/contracts on focus.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Guidelines for spacing (allow room for focus expansion) and consistency (use uniform sizes within rows/groups).

sections.title: Cards
sections.summary: Card lockups combine header, footer, and content view for presenting ratings and reviews for media items.

sections.title: Caption buttons
sections.summary: Caption buttons include title/subtitle beneath the button, can contain image or text, and should tilt in the direction of user swipe when focused.

sections.title: Monograms
sections.summary: Monograms identify people (cast/crew) with circular picture and name. Images preferred over initials for personal connection.

sections.title: Posters
sections.summary: Posters consist of image with optional title/subtitle hidden until focus. Size should be appropriate for content.

sections.title: Platform considerations
sections.summary: Lockups are not supported on iOS, iPadOS, macOS, visionOS, or watchOS - tvOS only.

sections.title: Resources
sections.summary: Links to related documentation (Designing for tvOS, Layout) and developer APIs (TVLockupView, TVLockupHeaderFooterView).

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document introduces lockups as tvOS UI components, explains their structure (header, content, footer), lists best practices for spacing and consistency, then details four lockup types (cards, caption buttons, monograms, posters) with illustrations and API references. Concludes with platform support information (tvOS only) and resource links.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that combines multiple separate views (header, content, footer) into a single, interactive unit
TVUIKit API class for creating lockup components on tvOS
TVUIKit API class for header and footer views within lockups
TVUIKit API class for card-style lockups displaying ratings and reviews
TVUIKit API class for caption buttons with title/subtitle beneath
TVUIKit API class for monograms identifying people with circular pictures
TVUIKit API class for poster lockups with images and optional titles
A lockup type that combines header, footer, and content view to present ratings and reviews for media items
A lockup type that includes a title and subtitle beneath the button, containing either an image or text
A lockup type that identifies people with a circular picture and name, showing initials if no image is available
A lockup type consisting of an image and optional title/subtitle that are hidden until focus

keyFindings: Lockups consist of three components: header (above content), content view, and footer (below content)
All three lockup views expand and contract together when the lockup receives focus
Four types of lockups exist: cards, caption buttons, monograms, and posters
Adequate spacing between lockups is required because focused lockups expand in size
Consistent lockup sizes within rows/groups improve visual appeal
Caption buttons should tilt in the direction of user swipe (vertical, horizontal, or both for grids)
For monograms, images of people are preferred over initials for a more intimate connection
Poster titles and subtitles are hidden until the poster receives focus
Lockups are exclusively supported on tvOS - not available on iOS, iPadOS, macOS, visionOS, or watchOS

apis.name: TVLockupHeaderFooterView
apis.purpose: Header and footer views for lockups

apis.name: TVCardView
apis.purpose: Card-style lockup for ratings and reviews

apis.name: TVPosterView
apis.purpose: Poster lockup with image and optional text

designDecisions.rationale: Focused lockups expand in size, requiring room to avoid overlapping or displacing other lockups

designDecisions.decision: Use consistent lockup sizes within rows/groups
designDecisions.rationale: Matching widths and heights create more visually appealing button groups and content rows

designDecisions.decision: Caption buttons should tilt with swipe motion
designDecisions.rationale: Provides visual feedback aligned with user interaction direction (vertical, horizontal, or both)

designDecisions.decision: Prefer images over initials for monograms
designDecisions.rationale: An image of a person creates a more intimate connection than text
Allows clean visual presentation with details revealed on demand through focus interaction

mainContent: Lockups combine multiple separate views into a single, interactive unit.

Each lockup consists of a content view, a header, and a footer. Headers appear above the main content for a lockup, and footers appear below the main content. All three views expand and contract together as the lockup gets focus.
According to the needs of your app, you can combine four types of lockup: cards, caption buttons, monograms, and posters.
Allow adequate space between lockups. A focused lockup expands in size, so leave enough room between lockups to avoid overlapping or displacing other lockups. For guidance, see Layout.
Use consistent lockup sizes within a row or group. A group of buttons or a row of content images is more visually appealing when the widths and heights of all elements match.
For developer guidance, see TVLockupView and TVLockupHeaderFooterView.
A card combines a header, footer, and content view to present ratings and reviews for media items.
A caption button can include a title and a subtitle beneath the button. A caption button can contain either an image or text.

Make sure that when people focus on them, caption buttons tilt with the motion that they swipe. When aligned vertically, caption buttons tilt up and down. When aligned horizontally, caption buttons tilt left and right. When displayed in a grid, caption buttons tilt both vertically and horizontally.

Monograms identify people, usually the cast and crew for a media item. Each monogram consists of a circular picture of the person and their name. If an image isn't available, the person's initials appear in place of an image.
Prefer images over initials. An image of a person creates a more intimate connection than text.

Posters consist of an image and an optional title and subtitle, which are hidden until the poster comes into focus. Posters can be any size, but the size needs to be appropriate for their content. For related guidance, see Image views.
Not supported in iOS, iPadOS, macOS, visionOS, or watchOS.
